class anki_vector.util.Distance(distance_mm=None, distance_inches=None)Â¶

Represents a distance.

The class allows distances to be returned in either millimeters or inches.

Use the distance_inches() or distance_mm() convenience methods to generate a Distance instance.

Parameters:

  • distance_inches (Optional[float]) â The number of inches the distance should represent (cannot be combined with distance_mm).

class anki_vector.util.Matrix44(m00, m10, m20, m30, m01, m11, m21, m31, m02, m12, m22, m32, m03, m13, m23, m33)Â¶

A 4x4 Matrix for representing the rotation and/or position of an object in the world.

Can be generated from a Quaternion for a pure rotation matrix, or combined with a position for a full translation matrix, as done by Pose.to_matrix().

forward_xyzÂ¶

tuple of 3 floats â The x,y,z components representing the matrixâs forward vector.

in_column_orderÂ¶

tuple of 16 floats â The contents of the matrix in column order.

in_row_orderÂ¶

tuple of 16 floats â The contents of the matrix in row order.

left_xyzÂ¶

tuple of 3 floats â The x,y,z components representing the matrixâs left vector.

pos_xyzÂ¶

tuple of 3 floats â The x,y,z components representing the matrixâs position vector.

set_forward(x, y, z)Â¶

Set the x,y,z components representing the matrixâs forward vector.

Parameters:
  • x (float) â The X component.
  • y (float) â The Y component.
  • z (float) â The Z component.
set_left(x, y, z)Â¶

Set the x,y,z components representing the matrixâs left vector.

Parameters:
  • x (float) â The X component.
  • y (float) â The Y component.
  • z (float) â The Z component.

  • x (float) â The X component.
  • y (float) â The Y component.
  • z (float) â The Z component.

  • z (float) â The Z component.

class anki_vector.util.Pose(x, y, z, q0=None, q1=None, q2=None, q3=None, angle_z=None, origin_id=-1)Â¶

Represents where an object is in the world.

Whenever Vector is delocalized (i.e. whenever Vector no longer knows where he is - e.g. when heâs picked up), Vector creates a new pose starting at (0,0,0) with no rotation, with origin_id incremented to show that these poses cannot be compared with earlier ones. As Vector drives around, his pose (and the pose of other objects he observes - e.g. faces, his LightCube, charger, etc.) is relative to this initial position and orientation.

The coordinate space is relative to Vector, where Vectorâs origin is the point on the ground between Vectorâs two front wheels. The X axis is Vectorâs forward direction, the Y axis is to Vectorâs left, and the Z axis is up.

Only poses of the same origin_id can safely be compared or operated on.

import anki_vector

with anki_vector.Robot() as robot:
    pose = anki_vector.util.Pose(x=50, y=0, z=0, angle_z=anki_vector.util.Angle(degrees=0))
    robot.behavior.go_to_pose(pose)
define_pose_relative_this(new_pose)Â¶

Creates a new pose such that new_poseâs origin is now at the location of this pose.

Parameters:new_pose (anki_vector.util.Pose) â The pose which origin is being changed.
Returns:A anki_vector.util.Pose object for which the origin was this poseâs origin.
is_comparable(other_pose)Â¶

Checks whether these two poses are comparable.

Poses are comparable if theyâre valid and having matching origin IDs.

Parameters:other_pose â The other pose to compare against. Type is Pose.
Returns:True if the two poses are comparable, False otherwise.
Return type:bool
is_validÂ¶

True if this is a valid, usable pose.

Return type:bool
origin_idÂ¶

An ID maintained by the robot which represents which coordinate frame this pose is in.

Return type:int
positionÂ¶

The position component of this pose.

Return type:Position
rotationÂ¶

The rotation component of this pose.

Return type:Quaternion
to_matrix()Â¶

Convert the Pose to a Matrix44.

Returns:A matrix representing this Poseâs position and rotation.
Return type:Matrix44
to_proto_pose_struct()Â¶

Converts the Pose into the robotâs messaging pose format.

Return type:PoseStruct
class anki_vector.util.Position(x, y, z)Â¶

Represents the position of an object in the world.

class anki_vector.util.Quaternion(q0=None, q1=None, q2=None, q3=None, angle_z=None)Â¶

Represents the rotation of an object in the world.

angle_zÂ¶

An Angle instance representing the z Euler component of the objectâs rotation.

Defined as the rotation in the z axis.

Return type:Angle
q0Â¶

The q0 (w) value of the quaternion.

Return type:float

Return type:float
q2Â¶

Return type:float
q3Â¶

Return type:float
to_matrix(pos_x=0.0, pos_y=0.0, pos_z=0.0)Â¶

Convert the Quaternion to a 4x4 matrix representing this rotation.

A position can also be provided to generate a full translation matrix.

Parameters:
  • pos_x (float) â The x component for the position.
  • pos_y (float) â The y component for the position.
  • pos_z (float) â The z component for the position.
Returns:

A matrix representing this Quaternionâs rotation, with the provided position (which defaults to 0,0,0).
Return type:

anki_vector.util.Matrix44

anki_vector.util.get_class_logger(module, obj)Â¶

Helper to create logger for a given class (and module).

import anki_vector

logger = anki_vector.util.get_class_logger("module_name", "object_name")
Parameters:
  • module (str) â The name of the module to which the object belongs.
  • obj (object) â the object that owns the logger.
Return type:

Logger
anki_vector.util.parse_command_args(parser=None)Â¶

Parses command line arguments.

Attempts to read the robot serial number from the command line arguments. If no serial number is specified, we next attempt to read the robot serial number from environment variable ANKI_ROBOT_SERIAL. If ANKI_ROBOT_SERIAL is specified, the value will be used as the robotâs serial number.

import anki_vector

import argparse

parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
parser.add_argument("--new_param")
args = anki_vector.util.parse_command_args(parser)
Parameters:parser (Optional[ArgumentParser]) â To add new command line arguments, pass an argparse parser with the new options already defined. Leave empty to use the defaults.
anki_vector.util.radians(radians)Â¶

An Angle instance set to the specified number of radians.

Return type:Angle
anki_vector.util.setup_basic_logging(custom_handler=None, general_log_level=None, target=None)Â¶

Helper to perform basic setup of the Python logger.

Parameters:
  • custom_handler (Optional[Handler]) â provide an external logger for custom logging locations
  • general_log_level (Optional[str]) â âDEBUGâ, âINFOâ, âWARNâ, âERRORâ or an equivalent constant from the logging module. If None then a value will be read from the VECTOR_LOG_LEVEL environment variable.
  • target (object) â The stream to send the log data to; defaults to stderr
